title: line of duty finale review ally ross
story: All those bleak hours, in the Edge Park Hotel, we thought you might have been passing secret messages to an Organised Crime Gang but now it turns out you were actually “looking at pornography” on that laptop.“Nothing illegal — nothing extreme,” you claimed.So what the hell was it then  Horny Protestant Housewives  Hot Balaclava Women  Or ­something more “specialist”, like “Sucking On Diesel” Along with the fate of the bike-less bike gang, it’s one of the enduring mysteries of a brain-frazzling final episode of BBC’s Line Of Duty, which had an unenviable choice to make on Sunday night.Create one of television’s biggest ever sensations by turning its greatest character, Ted, into the criminal mastermind H Or risk frustrating viewers by playing a longer and more complicated game  Wisely, I thought, it chose the latter.Before we got to the big reveal, though, Ted and DCS Patricia Carmichael, played by the brilliant Anna Maxwell Martin, treated viewers to a mesmerising interrogation scene that was overflowing with numbers, images, documents, death stares, laptop revelations, VPNs and a whole lot of WTFs.With all of it initially turning on a bungled “section ” arrest by ­Carmichael’s striking-looking sidekick DI Brandyce, which had her boss demanding she put in “a transfer request”.Ideally to Last Of The Summer Wine or a Pogues tribute band.Seasoned viewers of this table-turning drama will have guessed where this one was heading from about the -minute mark, though, when lawyer Gill Biggeloe arrived with about as much ­subtlety as Bet Lynch on a Space Hopper.Artful it sometimes wasn’t, with the dialogue also veering between the brilliant and Fleming’s Scooby Doo-ishly awful line: “Something’s not right. And we need to find out what.”It wasn’t, however, until Gill Biggeloe was unmasked as the latest bad apple, that the episode really lost the plot.Firstly by trying to repeat series four’s “Urgent exit required” text trick.Then by turning sweet, little ginger Tina, who went for Biggeloe in the toilet with a kne, into a member of the OCG death cult. And finally by asking us to believe DI Cottan’s death twitches signalled four people were H.For some, I know, this will have been a step too far, but I’m still keeping the LoD faith.It may demand a lot of viewers and take risks, but that’s what all great dramas should do.And,some don’t come off, it’s one of the few home-made shows that can usually fall back on its script or the astonishing performances of its cast.Particular plaudits this series, of course, go to Adrian Dunbar who’s turned Superintendent Ted Hastings into a television legend and, in these crucyingly right-on times, reminded us how much the public still loves a strong male character.I don’t expect such an important message to register with BBC drama, where every overpaid moron in the building will be running around shouting: “We need a female Ted.” But that’s their funeral.Line Of Duty will still have over ten million viewers hooked, whenever it s, because, as we learned in the closing credits, its integrity, storyline and main characters all endure: Arnott’s been exonerated after shooting Tina.OCG member Ryan’s at police training college. Gill ­Biggeloe’s “been given a new identity”and flawed hero Ted Hastings is back in charge at AC- where he’s free to complete his Edge Park Hotel TripAdvisor review.“Faulty toilet, no guests, great wi-fi connection.”MY COLUMN s in a fortnight. In the meantime, can I recommend you watch the actor-to-stuntman handover, about four minutes into tonight’s EastEnders, as a topless Keanu escapes down Louise Mitchell’s drainpipe ’Costhat segment doesn’t win the Best Comedy Weight Loss category, something’s gone terribly wrong at next month’s Soap Awards.Piers Morgan: “My collar size used to be  and a half, it got to  and I didn’t like it.”And who would, on their first day at school But let’s talk about the here and now, Chunk.A MAJOR shock during the final episode of Channel ’s absorbing Sunday night series Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins.Rugby player Ben Foden voluntarily withdrew, during the interrogation phase, having been subjected to several hours of “disturbing and repetitive noises”.The one thing you’d think he was prepared for, after marrying one of The Saturdays.Whatever demons those ungodly howls awoke in Ben, they didn’t seem to bother Frankie Bridge’s husband Wayne, who’s been the obvious and deserving winner of the series since episode one.The final was still well worth an hour of your time, though, just to see the interrogation of Made In Cha’s Sam Thompson, whose endless backchat, sulking and general toddler antics went down every bit as well as you’d expect with the show’s battle-hardened Special Forces veterans.“Are you pulling a fookin’ face ” “No, Sir.” “Then stop being a fookin’ c*** then.”When verbal threats failed to register, the staff tried guilt-tripping him by menacing Victoria Pendleton with two alsatians.A tactic that probably went down badly with all those people who think the real SAS operates like a community outreach theatre group, pacying hostile forces through the medium of dance and mime.Personally, I thought the whole series was so brilliantly executed it should become an annual fixture, with celebrities forced to do it at gunpointnecessary.And,anyone disagrees, just try telling me you wouldn’t like to see Gemma Collins shoved out of a helicopter backwards.THIS Morning, April , “The woman who can predict the future by throwing asparagus”, Jemima Packington: “Meghan’s going to have the baby by the end of April. Twins, one boy, one girl. By the end of April.”And I’m sure the other one will be out any moment, Jemima.Glenn Hoddle: “The defender’s lying down completely flat with his legs in the air.”APOLOGIES for the recent lack of EastEnders updates.Five months seemed a safe enough gap to leave, and I’m pleased to report the coupling’s been forgotten by everyone – including Louise Mitchell, who was blackmailing Sharon over the affair.There now also seem to be more people living at the Slaters’ house than in Basingstoke – and Robert Kazinsky has even ed from Hollywood to reprise his role as Jean’s prodigal son Sean, having clearly benefited from the experience of landing such stellar parts as Randy in Hot Pursuit and George Jetson in Robot Chicken.The bad news, though, is that EastEnders is on to its sixth version of the endlessly useless Ben Mitchell and, having gone through his gay, incontinent ballet dancer phase, this one clearly thinks he’s Michael Caine, trying to put the heat on Lola’s Geordie boyfriend with this less-than-menacing line: “I’m gonna come up to Noocastle, to that grotty little flat, above that grotty little shop, in Westgate, and I’m gonna kill ya. Any questions ”Just one.How come you’re not deaf any more No. But it is a really terrible f***ing idea. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: price tag of the eu elections no one wants soars by another 50m
story: Theresa May repeatedly said it would be unacceptable for Britain to have to take part in the European polls to elect a new raft of MEPs, but now shes got no choice as shes not secured a Brexit deal yet.But today Cabinet Minister David Lidington told the BBC: Given how little time there is, its regrettable not going to be possible to finish that process before its legally due for the European Parliamentary elections.Legally, they do have to take place... so those will now go ahead.We will be redoubling our efforts and talks with MPs of all parties to make sure the delay is as short as possible.He said ideally MEPs would never have to take their seats in the European Parliament, and it would be done and dusted by the summer recess.The PMs spokesperson said this afternoon Mrs May deeply regretted having to take part.They said: She understands that many members of the public will feel deeply frustrated about this.MP Tom Pursglove blasted: Simply shouldnt be happening. Theres no getting away from the fact we could have left by now.People will be furious being asked to vote in elections they never wanted and which shouldnt be on.Tories have already blasted the elections as a total waste of money that could be far better spent as we leave the EU.And now its emerged that the cost is set to rocket from around £million to £million since the elections were last held.The extra cash includes £.million of money to be set aside for parties which could have to be reimbursedthe representatives never take up their seats.Deposits for those who say they will stand will have to be repaidthe election is scrapped, the Dailyreported.Staffing and officers will come to around £million and another £million is earmarked for posting out polling cards and information.Brexiteer MP Peter Bone told the paper: It’s a complete waste of public money because there is absolutely no need for these elections, and it should be spent on things people care about, whether that’s operations in hospitals or more police on the streets.Government sources insisted the money was going up because there were no other elections happening on that day, unlike in .The Tories are set for a drubbing in the upcoming poll, as voters punish them for failing to deliver Brexit.Meanwhile, Nigel Farages Brexit party are set to dominate, and are on track to WIN the election, one bombshell poll revealed.The PM is still in talks with Labour over a possible deal in the hope they can avoid taking part in the polls, or take part in them but the candidates never take their seats up.Discussions between the Government and the Opposition were set to take place this afternoon, and Mrs May was rumoured to offer them a customs union deal soft Brexit.However, MPs from both sides are fuming with their leaders.Tories hate the idea of a customs union which would deliver us a soft Brexit without the ability to get trade deals done with countries around the world.And Labour MPs are demanding a second referendum on leaving the EU as the price of their support - something neither Mr Corbyn nor Mrs May want to promise.

title: meghan markle royal baby charles teddy bear
story: The proud Prince of Wales, , made the comments on a tour of Germany as he chatted to well-wishers about Harry and Meghans newborn.Baby Sussex, who is yet to be named, arrived at .am yesterday weighing lb z.The baby boy is currently with mum Meghan, dad Prince Harry and grandma Doria Ragland at home in Frogmore Cottage.Charles was already beaming and in very high spirits along with the Duchess of Cornwall, as they arrived on German soil earlier today.The Prince of Wales spoke publicly about his new grandson, saying he was absolutely “delighted”.Charles, , and Camilla, , were greeted by hundreds of well-wishers on the first day of their Brexit charm offensive tour of Germany.During an official meeting with the German president, Charles was given a teddy bear wearing blue clothes for Baby Sussex.The prince beamed as President Frank-Walter Steinmeier said: “First of all, let me congratulate you.”On a walkabout in Berlin, where Camilla was handed a onesie and a balloon with the words, Its a boy across it, Charles said: “We couldn’t be more delighted at the news and we’re looking forward to meeting the baby when we .”They ended their afternoon engagements with a visit to Berlins Brandenburg Gate, where hundreds gathered to pass on their congratulations.Replying to one comment of Congratulations on the new grandchild, Charles said: Thank you, Im collecting a rather large number of them.Askedhe had seen the baby yet, Charles said: Not yet. How many grandchildren have you got  None yet  Just you wait.Charles now boasts four grandchildren, with Baby Sussex joining his cousins Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis of Cambridge.The Prince had already expressed his delight following the announcement of the birth, as it was thought he might miss out.Charles reportedly believes this German tour is of great importance, but with a close bond to his daughter in law Meghan, he was reportedly reluctant to miss the birth.His comments follow a heartwarming message from his son Prince William and Kate Middleton.Last night, the pair said they were delighted and couldnt wait to see the latest addition to the family.The Duke of Cambridge, , said he was “absolutely thrilled” about the birth of Baby Sussex and was looking forward to seeing his new nephew.His we Kate, , also told of her delight at a spring baby — before warning Meghan about the “daunting” days ahead.Asked how he felt during a tour of the Cutty Sark in South East London yesterday, William replied: “Obviously thrilled, absolutely thrilled.“And obviously looking forward to seeing them in the next few days when things have quietened down.“I’m very pleased and glad to welcome my own brother into the sleep deprivation society that is parenting.”Baby Sussex, who has yet to be named, was born at a private hospital at .am on Monday, weighing lb oz.Askedhe had any pearls of wisdom for Harry, , dad-of-three William laughed and said: “Plenty of advice, plenty of advice.“But no, I wish him all the best and I hope the next few days they can settle down and enjoy having a newborn in their family and the joys that come with that.”Kate, dressed in a chic Breton striped top and £ LK Bennett trousers added: “It’s such a special time, obviously with Louis and Charlotte just having had their birthdays it’s such a great time of year to have a baby. Spring is in the air.”Kate said she and William have not yet had the chance to see Harry and Meghan’s newborn — and had no clues about his name.She said: “As William said, we’re looking forward to meeting him and finding out what his name’s going to be so it’s really exciting for both of them and we wish them all the best.“These next few weeks are always a bit daunting the first time round.”Over the next four days, Charles and Camilla will travel to Berlin, Leipzig and Munich to highlight the UK and Germanys shared history and culture.To mark their arrival in the capital, there was a Guard of Honour from the countrys Federal Defence Forces.The couple have met Chancellor Angela Merkel at the Federal Chancellory before attending a meeting her in private study.They will then travel to Schloss Bellevue where they will be welcomed by the President of Germany, Frank-Walter Steinmeier.After a private meeting with the president, Charles and Camilla will visit and walk through Brandenburg Gate with the Mayor of Berlin, Michael Muller.Mr Muller will give the couple a brief history of the gate, as well as explaining its importance to the city.The prince and the duchess will then take the opportunity to meet members of the public outside the famous landmark.For their final engagement of the day, the couple will attend the Queens Birthday Party at the British Ambassadors residence.Charles will deliver a speech at the annual event in which he will emphasise the importance of an enduring relationship between the UK and Germany despite their relations currently being in transition.

title: pro remain change uk have twitter handle hijacked by hard brexit pranksters in latest blunder from new party
story: The anti-Brexit party was humiliated yet again after they changed their Twitter address from @TheIndGroup to @ForChange_Now.All their tweets and followers have been moved over to the new address.But the old one was immediately seized by jokers, who started using it to tweet out pro-Brexit messages.The account tweeted copies of the Conservative manesto, which promised to leave the EU.It also put out a picture of one of the groups MPs, Anna Soubry, with the fake quote: Id like to apologise to the British people for the absolute f**king state of me and my views.And they added: Remember, the people that cannot operate a twitter account want you to give them a shot at running the country. I can see why they want the EU to do it for them.The party sent out a message from their new account saying their website and Twitter address had changed.But their website and emails were still redirecting to the old social media address this afternoon.Interim leader Heidi Allens account was still pointing people to the joke handle too.The gaffe is just the latest in a string of humiliations for the new party, which launched earlier this year.One of its candidates was forced to stand down within hours of being revealed - over offensive online comments.Ali Sadjady wrote on Twitter: “When I hear that  per cent of pick pockets caught on the London Underground are Romanian it kind of makes me want Brexit.”And despite pledging to support another referendum, he also wrote back in  that it would be a slap in the face of democracy.A blank space will also appear on the ballot papers later this month for the party - after their logo was rejected by the elections watchdog for having a hashtag in it.All other parties will have a logo there instead.On the partys launch today in February, Labour defector Angela Smith had to apologise for appearing to use the phrase “funny tinge” to describe ethnic minority people.Then when the rebel MPs – eight from Labour and three from the Tories – said they wanted to be known as Change UK they were hit with an angry response from petition website Change.org.Brits are also confused about what the official name for the party is.Theyve known to go by Change UK, The Independent Group, TIG, The Tiggers and other names.The For Change Now handle is likely to confuse their brand even more.The party wants a peoples vote on Brexit to try and overturn the result of the referendum and stay in the EU.The party have been approached for comment.

title: meghan markle prince harry birth misled
story: A couple of weeks ago, that most “woke” of royal couples, Meghan and Harry, made a self-important statement to say there would be no statement about the forthcoming birth of the  squillionth in line to the throne.The nation stopped what they were doing for a moment, muttered “Yer what ” then gave a collective shrug and carried on trying to pay the bills.Then came yesterday’s weird stage management of what could have been a simple “They’ve had a healthy baby boy” statement made at a time that suited them.Instead, at pm, Buckingham Palace announced that the Duchess of Sussex was “in labour” then,  minutes later, followed it up with the news that it was a lb oz boy who, it later transpired, had arrived in the world in the early hours of that morning.So why the smoke and mirrors nonsense  It begs the question: If they put out misinformation about something so innocent, why should we believe what they say in any future statements As the old saying goes, “Don’t start drama and then say you hate drama”.Prince Harry has a special place in our hearts for many reasons, but particularly because he lost his mother at such a young age and was forced by royal duty to walk behind her coffin in full view of the world — a move that, today, seems even more unthinkable than it did then.So it’s understandable that he wanted to keep that most private of moments — the birth of his first child — out of the public gaze for a few precious hours. Fair enough.Equally, no one was much bothered whether or not Meghan came out on the steps of a hospital  seconds after giving birth. Each to their own and all that.But being Hollywood-style “woke” means you can’t just quietly get on with it and let your actions speak for themselves.No, you have to make grand declarations about your right-on credentials, such as “climate change is a very important issue” or “racism is abhorrent” as , by not making such virtue-signalling statements, the rest of us disagree and need to be enlightened.And so, rather than just announcing the birth when it suited them, they issued a rather pompous and bewildering press release to tell us in advance that they wanted to “keep the plans around the arrival of their baby private”.Asthe Press and public were constantly banging on the door of their easily accessible, terraced house, demanding to knowlittle Wayne or Waynetta had arrived yet.This push-back, following as it did the very public ghosting of Meghan’s father Thomas, risked alienating those members of the public with a genuine fondness for the prince and his new we.But happily, all the nonsense was forgotten the moment Harry bounded in to the stables area at Windsor Castle, where a select few of the world’s media were assembled.As the horses behind him gazed disinterestedly into the middle distance, his obvious delight at becoming a father was written all over his face.This was the Labrador puppy-esque Harry of old, and thanks to his excellent “How women do that is beyond comprehension” remark, he’s now firmly reinstated as the uncomplicated, cheeky chappie we all have a soft spot for.So, a heartfelt congratulations to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex on the birth of their first child.And moving forward, perhaps a little less of the stage-management and self-important virtue-signalling would be wise.In other words, take a leaf out of our admirable Queen’s book and just show us what you’re made of, rather than tell.PRINCESS CHARLOTTE celebrated her fourth birthday last week with a party at Kensington Palace.One can only imagine what a hot ticket that was at her primary school.Not among the children, silly. I mean the parents.The fevered anticipation at school pick-up time must have been palpable.Is there a gilt-edged stfyin the backpack or not Should they wait until they’re in the car before looking Or should they just fall to their knees in the playground right now for a spot of desperate, unseemly rummaging In the event, Prince William described it as “a rowdy party” which suggests that he and Kate swerved any potential breach of social etiquette by inviting the whole class. Phew.But of course, small children, the elderly or infirm would have had no chance in the face of such disastrous selfishness.QUEEN the band are now richer than our actual monarch following the worldwide success of their movie Bohemian Rhapsody.Guitarist Brian May and drummer Roger Taylor are the brains behind the biopic, which focuses on former frontman Freddie Mercury, who died in .But perhaps the smartest of them all is bassist John Deacon, who, despite being asked to be involved in the planning and production of the movie, didn’t even reply to the email – preferring to live a non-famous, quiet le in West London with his we and kids.While still benefiting from the enormous royalty cheques, of course.SO let’s get this straight. We need to promote activities, services, experiences which connect people and which you just can’t do sitting at home.’But Mr Brokenshire’s comments threatened to spark ridicule from store giants furious at Government apathy over the , high street jobs that have been lost in the last year alone.Mr Brokenshire also criticised town halls for hitting motorists with sky-high parking fees - and suggested that had also had an impact on falling footfall.And he made an appeal to Brits to do their own bit to save high streets with a new ‘think before you click’ attitude.He said: “Next time you flip open the laptop or browse on your mobile for that new outfit for yourself or toys for the children or a special gt for a friend, think about taking a trip out to bag that bargain. It’s often onlyyou touch it, see it and try it that you’ll know it’s right for you.“That’s what will continue to make our high streets special in providing experiences which shopping from the sofa can simply never do.”The Government has spent £ billion in business rate support to help high street stores and has overhauled planning rules to make it easier to build new homes above shops and at the centre of towns and cities.Last year Chancellor Philip Hammond pledged £ million to the Future High Streets Fund to reinvigorate high streets.And Mr Brokenshire also pointed to the Government’s Open Doors’ project that will allow empty high street outlets to be taken over by community groups.“Councils have an important role to play in designing and supporting the vibrant town centres of our future.“It is, of course, up to local authorities to set parking charges but I would urge all councils to think carefully before introducing sharp increases that could turn more people into stay at home shoppers.“Councillors in Ashford saw a surge in shoppers in their town centre after they cut parking fees and put on popular public events to encourage people back to the high street.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. He’s playing an emotional game.” After a meeting with David Davis, then Brexit secretary, Crosse says his “head in the f***ing clouds.” She then sneers at the “war spirit” invoked by the PM in her speech.The two-part BBC series, which begins on Wednesday, shows Verhofstadt and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier mocking Britain.When Mrs May arrived on stage at her conference twerking to Dancing Queen, Verhofstadt backs a suggestion that Barnier should walk on to The Winner Takes It All.Roberto Gualtieri, Italian member of the European Parliament’s Brexit Steering Group, says: “When Barnier enters, we should play The Winner Takes It All.”Verhofstadt then adds: “That would be sexier.”Elmar Brok, a German Christian Democrat MEP, says the EU must do nothing to help Britain whilst the country is “in a mess.” “They have to come to us,” he urges.Belgian filmmaker Lode Desmet was given exclusive access to Verhofstadt, and his close knit team, for two years.Michel Barnier, asking whether the EU should negotiate with then Brexit Secretary David David or Downing Street adviser Olly Robbins, says his team needs someone “stable, available and reliable” to talk to.Verhofstadt, the European Parliament’s Brexit boss, sarcastically replies: “We can’t ask too much of Britain, don’t overdo it.”NO more repugnant figure struts the ­corridors of Brussels than the curtain-haired slimeball Guy Verhofstadt.Try as they might, even the drunk Juncker or the peacock Barnier cannot match the Belgian’s detestable blabbermouthed arroganceAnd his top aide plainly shares his superiority complex. “I’m most proud of you when you take on a Tory and win,” coos Edel Rettman Crosse sycophantically to her ageing boss. “You should shoot the f***ers out.”“That’s the game,” replies Verhofstadt, the European Parliament’s Brexit chief.So it wasn’t just Britain they set out to humiliate. It was Tories specically.Indeed the new fly-on-the-wall EU documentary is a revealing portrait of the pompous, sneering, undemocratic bureaucrats .million of us voted to leave: mocking Brexit, our country, even our “war spirit”. That’s right, the war spirit that served us well as we helped to liberate Europe from Nazi tyranny.But for an insight into Verhofstadt’s blinkered stupidity look no further than a remark he made only yesterday.Turkey, he said, was “drting towards dictatorship” as its president orders the re-run of an election he lost.Precisely as Brussels does with its own defeats and is desperate to do with Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bubbly hard working woman took
story: NewsBubbly and hard-working woman took own le after being chased for £,Samantha Ewen, , from Hull, was facing financial woes including a debt from an accident that wasnt her fault when she took her own leShareCommentsByTom Kershaw:,  MAY NewsSamantha Ewen, , who was found dead in her home in Hull "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman took her own le because the £, debt she owed for an accident that wasnapost her fault had become much to bear, an inquest has heard. Bubbly and hard-working graphic designer Samantha Ewen, , was found dead in her home in west Hull by her parents on October , . An hearing at Hull Coroneraposs Court today heard she had taken her own le after she grew out of her depth with mounting debts.Samantha left several notes at her home, including one to police saying she had killed herself, reports Hull Live .Another note, written to her parents and her sister, said Ms Ewen had received a high court writ after a friend had driven her car without insurance and injured a cyclist during an accident in ,    In the note, Samantha said she had no prior knowledge of the accident and the claim was for £,.  The note read: I became out of my depth. I am sorry for the mess I have left you with, this was my mistake. I love you all to the moon and back. Paying tribute, a statement from her mother read: Growing up, Samantha was a very happy, bubbly and social girl. She learnt languages with ease and when we moved to South Africa she picked up the Afrikaans language. She has the South African way of making a plan to find a solution. She was very good in that mindset and was a hard worker. Samantha, who had attended Brough Primary School and for a year at South Hunsley Secondary School, had previously sought medication for depression, but was happy according to her family. She had wanted to secure a job in Eswatini, also known as Swaziland, in southern Africa where her mum and dad moved to when she was aged , however, she was unable to get a work permit due to her British citizenship and ed to Hull with her sister Kirsty.    Samantha had worked in public relations and marketing job sectors and worked at Viking FM and set up a marketing company with her then husband which led her to becoming a graphic designer. She then launched her own company Curious Echo in , where she produced work for NHS trusts across the country. Her mother told the inquest that her daughter revealed she worked until am or am and was very dedicated to making her business work. She had even allowed Samantha to borrow large sums of money from her to see her through after payments from her clients dropped. However, she never mentioned the payments as it would hurt her daughteraposs pride. However, Samantha struggled to keep her head above the water, and admitted not keeping up to date with her tax s in her suicide note. Her death had been pre-planned and she had organised her parents to dog-sit her two pets the night that she chose to take her own le, the hearing was told. Samanthaaposs parents entered her property at around .pm on October  last year to see the heartbreaking note on her unlocked front door to read their daughteraposs body would be tragically found inside. Humberside Police officer Hayley Browne said there were no suspicious circumstances or third party involvement in Samanthaaposs death. Returning a conclusion of suicide, area coroner Rosemary Baxter said: Samantha had been in fact struggling with le in the months before her death. She was struggling financially and she felt she was a failure. Her death was a pre-planned act and her many problems overcame her at the end and the notes she left at the scene determined her le was taken deliberately by her own hand.

, title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers have been told to get a grip after leaving claimants to wait months for disability payments in a benefits row.One Universal Credit claimant is owed nearly £, while another has been waiting nine months, MPs heard today.The row involves , disabled people who lost aposSevere Disability Premiumsapos when they moved to Universal Credit. The government is offering them transition cash and a one-off back payment after accepting many of them lost out. Yet months after the last claimants moved to UC in January, the Department for Work and Pensionsstill hasnapost coughed up that extra money. Instead, it is on hold because the cash is tied up with wider UC regulations that havenapost passed into law.And the claimants could now face yet another delay after the High Court ruled the cash pot was unlawful.A judge last week backed two claimants who argued the back payments, worth just £ per month, short-changed them by around £.    Despite the long delay so far, Tory Justin Tomlinson today said the DWP has not yet decided whether to appeal the High Court case or cough up the money, or how. title: mps vote banning wild animals
story: NewsMPs vote on banning wild animals from circuses after years of delaysThe Bill will make it an offence for an operator of a travelling circus in England to use a "wild animal" in the circusShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsCampaigners say it is long overdue "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMPs are voting on whether or not to ban wild animals from circuses after years of delays. The Bill will make it an offence for an operator of a travelling circus in England to use a wild animal in the circus. Should MPs agree, travelling circuses in England which currently use wild animals will have until  January  before it becomes an offence to use the wild animal in exhibition or performance. There are currently  wild animals left in travelling circuses.But critics say the new bill only comes after years of heel dragging from the Tories and campaigning from charities, activists and Labour .The bill is virtually identical to Trudy Harrison MP’s Ten Minute Rule Private Member’s Bill which was co-sponsored by Sue Hayman MP, introduced on th March , which had not yet received a Second Reading . There have been several similar Private Member’s Bills in previous Parliaments: - - Kevin Foster MP - - Will Quince MP - - Jim Fitzpatrick MP - - Thomas Docherty MP. In  the then- Labour government consulted on introducing a ban on the use of wild animals in travelling circuses, with the proposals receiving % support.    The Coalition Government said in  it wanted to look into a ban on ethical grounds but needed to change the law because there was not enough evidence that a ban could be justied on welfare grounds. In the meantime the Government introduced a licensing scheme under the Animal Welfare Act . The Welfare of Wild Animals in Travelling CircusesRegulations  came into force on  January  and are set to expire on  January . Last year DEFRA confirmed the government would not be renewing the regulations. Only two travelling circuses have been licensed under the  Regulations to use wild animal acts. The Government published a post- implementation review of the Regulations in January . The Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Select Committeeaposs main recommendation that the ban should not apply to all wild animals was not accepted by the Government. The Wild Animals in Travelling CircusesAct  already prohibits the use of wild animals in travelling circuses in Scotland. The Welsh Government consulted on a ban in October  after an independent review of the evidence on animal welfare of wild animals in travelling and non-travelling circuses and has announced a ban will be introduced in . Meanwhile, the Northern Ireland Executive has investigated the possibility of an all-island approach to the issue of wild animals in circuses through adoption of a Code of Practice. The Republic of Ireland banned wild animals in circuses in .  Ahead of the billaposs second reading, Environment Secretary Michael Gove said: Travelling circuses are no place for wild animals in the st century and I am pleased that this legislation will put an end to this practice for good. Today’s announcement follows other measures we have taken to strengthen our position as a world leader on animal protection. This includes our ban on ivory sales to protect elephants, and delivering Finn’s Law to strengthen the protection of service animals.

title: peterborough voters sick tired brexit
story: NewsPeterborough voters sick and tired of Brexit as they prepare to pick new MPLocals are angry at the actions of disgraced former MP Fiona OnasanyaShareByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsBill Marriott was scornful of both the Tories and Labours prospects "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Voters go to the polls in Peterborough next month in a crunch by-election that could have a direct impact on Brexit .In a Parliament where every vote counts, the result of the ballot in the Cambridgeshire constituency could have a big influence on the shape of EU withdrawal.It is a Leave-supporting marginal that was held by the Conservatives until , then dramatically switched to Labour in the unexpected surge for Jeremy Corbyn .But the victorious MP Fiona Onasanya, who won by just  votes, was jailed earlier this year after being convicted of lying over speeding points. The former solicitor refused to quit the Commons but last week the electorate took the decision out of her hands and she became the first-ever MP to be ousted through a recall petition. Now, Labour, the Tories and the new Brexit Party, led by Nigel Farage, who holds a rally in the city tonight, will battle it out with other parties until polling day on June .    The Brexit Party is yet to unveil its candidate for what will be its first election for a Westminster seat, where three in five voters backed Leave. Sprightly -year-old Bill Marriott, who was cycling to the swimming pool for an afternoon dip, was scornful of both Labour and the Toriesapos prospects. “Labour donapost know which way they want to go, they are arguing among themselves,” said the retired Tesco produce manager.“When Theresa May first came to power I thought she was going to be another Maggie Thatcher but she lost her way. Itaposs a great pity.”Bill went on: “Iaposm sick and tired of Brexit. When it comes on the TV I switch it off, Iaposm sick to death of it. “Regardless of what people voted – for or against – these politicians and MPs should respect the wishes of the public and get on with it and stop squabbling among themselves. “Nigel Farageaposs party is going to have a lot of votes. Heaposs very well known and will certainly liven Peterborough up a bit and put it in the spotlight.”  Civil servant Linda Woodham, , signed the petition to oust Onasanya. “Itaposs the start of politicians being held accountable for their actions,” she said in between bites of an iced doughnut as she sat on a bench during her lunch break. Linda believed the fight could be dominated by domestic issues such as “housing, school places and hospitals” – which could help Labour and hit the Conservatives. But she added: “The Brexit Party will get a lot of support. “Nigel Farage has been here a couple of times, he has shown an interest.” Lindaaposs pal Tina Jones, , said of Onasanyaaposs fall from grace: “I donapost see how she could carry on. “I donapost understand how you can be an MPyouaposve got a criminal record.” Retired salesman Graham Raywood, , agreed, saying: “In a nutshell, itaposs a ludicrous situation. “Here you have someone thataposs supposed to have legal training and is prepared to sacrice her livelihood, her reputation, for basically trying to avoid three points on her licence. It makes no sense at all.    “Even someone without legal training would have just taken the points. “I donapost understand the risk.” He believed the by-election will be tight, with a campaign focused on Brexit and immigration. “Peterborough is obviously very marginal,” said Graham. “The big issue is immigration and thataposs what will probably get the next candidate elected. “Brexit is always an issue – people are getting fed up with it now.”Told former MP and ex-Celebrity Big Brother star George Galloway will fight the seat, Graham said: “And his credibility is what  Impersonating a cat on TV ”Bar maid Hannah McIntosh, , will not vote on June . “I have no interest in politics, I know nothing that they stand for,” she said. “I didnapost vote in the referendum, I donapost know enough to make an educated guess. “I guess I mightI felt like politics was affecting my le directly, but at the minute nothing does.” Hannahaposs boss Sean Page, , who plans to spoil his ballot paper, described Farage as “a bit of a tw*t”. He said: “The manner in which he tries to present a lot of his thoughts comes across as very bigoted.”  Asked why Farage might find Peterborough an attractive target, he added: “We have a lot of aposforeignersapos looking to work – they are just looking for a job. “They come here and then you have the Brit that sits there going, aposI canapost get a job but all these people around me are getting jobsapos. “Thataposs probably why thereaposs that ignorance in a lot of voters.” Sean believes Brexit chaos has unleashed “uncertainty” - and was keen to highlight what he saw as his cityaposs ersity. “Peterborough has historically been a very multicultural city,” he said.    “Iaposm a second-generation immigrant – my grandfather came from Italy to work in the brickyards. “Thereaposs a massive Pakistani and Indian contingent in Peterborough, a huge east European contingent. “I donapost see it clashing but there are quite segregated parts of the city.”  Chris Killigrew, , has run a plant stall in Cathedral Square for seven years. She had no sympathy for Onasanya, who lasted  months as the cityaposs MP.    “Iaposm glad sheaposs gone, I donapost think she should be in a position of power after all that,” said Chris. She believes Brexit will dominate the campaign, three years after the city voted to quit the EU. “Itaposs still very much to Leave – thereaposs anger that we havenapost left yet,” said Chris. In a familiar complaint against politicians, she said voters were “fed up of them all”. In more bad news for Jeremy Corbyn and the Prime Minister, she thinks the Brexit Party could attract big support as electors shun the two main parties. Echoing fears about the impact of immigration on this corner of the country, she went on: “Thereaposs a big community of Polish and east Europeans in Peterborough and surrounding areas. “There are waits for doctorsapos and hospital appointments – you canapost get a dentist.” But she might also boycott the poll. “Iaposm tempted not to vote at all because there doesnapost seem any point,” she said. “We voted Brexit but itaposs not happening and itaposs never going to be a full-on Brexit.” Romanian Avram Jianu, , came to the UK when he was three years old and believes racism has increased since the  referendum.    Avram, who was selling toys from a stall and also works in a Marks and Spencer warehouse, said in slightly broken English and with a Yorkshire accent: “Here there are a lot of immigrants, east Europeans. “I have noticed a change in how people look at me since Brexit – they think I am stealing, I rob them. “They think I come into England to steal. I am working, I am paying taxes.” He too believes Brexit will be the major theme of the by-election. “Brexit will make the Pound go down. Food is getting expensive but the wages stay the same,” he said. “When people voted, they didnapost know what they voted for. “Young people didnapost vote, it was people in their s, s and s who voted to leave.” Youngsters, along with everyone  in Peterborough aged  and over, will have their chance to vote next month, deciding whether they boost Labouraposs hopes of winning a general election or whether they give the PM an unexpected bounce. Or whether they hand victory to the Brexit Party.

title: tories admit uk take part
story: NewsTories admit UK WILL take part in EU elections despite Theresa Mays Brexit vowCabinet minister David Lidington confirmed there is not enough time to get a Brexit deal through Parliament to avoid taking part in the £million electionsShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY NewsThe news is further humiliation for Theresa May "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Tories have finally admitted the UK will have to take part in EU elections despite Theresa May vowing to stop them going ahead. Senior cabinet minister David Lidington confirmed there was now not enough time to get a Brexit deal through Parliament.And he admitted that the UK may not now leave the European Union until August , after the start of MPs’ summer recess. Downing Street said the Prime Minister “deeply regrets” the elections - which could cost an estimated £m - going ahead. The humiliating admission comes despite repeated assurances by Mrs May that she was determined to prevent voters going to the polls. In March, she told MPs: “As Prime Minister I am not prepared to delay Brexit any further than the June .” The increased pressure on her already fragile leadership came as the Tories backbench chief again told her to set a departure date.  Sir Graham Brady, chairman of the  committee, was thought to have warned her that unless she did she could face another challenge. Grassroots Tory activists will also hold an emergency summit in June to hold a no confidence vote in the PM.Cross-party Brexit talks kicked off again today with Labour sources downplaying claims they were ready to strike a deal. Both Mrs May and Jeremy Corbyn had said last week’s poor local election results showed the public wanted them to get on with Brexit.The key issue of a customs union was still iding the parties with Labour MPs insisting there would need to be a confirmatory public vote while Tory MPs warning the compromise could permanently fracture the party. Foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt said: “I’m not a believer in a customs union as a sustainable long-term solution.” Mr Lidington claimed the Government was “redoubling our efforts” to get its Brexit deal ratied by the start of July, so  MEPs elected on May  month will never have to take their seats. But he admitted wrangling could continue until MPs go on their summer holidays, delaying Brexit Day until August  when MEPs would give up their seats after just three weeks.    “We very much hoped that we would be able to get our exit sorted and have the treaty concluded so that those elections did not have to take place. But legally they do have to take place... so those will now go ahead,” he said. “But we will be redoubling our efforts and talks with MPs of all parties to try to make sure that the delay after that is as short as possible. “Ideally we’d like to be in a situation where those MEPs never actually have to take their seat at European Parliament - certainly, to get this done and dusted by the summer recess.” The PM’s spokesman admitted the public would feel “great frustration” that the elections were taking place. Tory MEP David Campbell Bannerman predicted the Tories would “get a kicking” and be down to  MEPs. The new Brexit Party could scoop up the Leave vote while Remain supporters could flock to pro-EU parties like the Lib Dems. It came as a handful of Brexiteer Tories hinted they could back a second referendum to resolve the issue once and for all.

story: NewsInside Meghan Markles luxury £k labour ward that serves champagne and lobsterPrince Harry and the Duchess of Sussex welcomed their baby boy yesterday at The Portland Hospital in LondonShareCommentsBySteve MyallDeputy Features EditorJane Lavender:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMeghan is reported to have given birth at the Portland Hospital "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailItaposs the birth weaposve all been waiting for and now the royal baby has finally arrived. The -year-old died from multiple injuries when he fell at the London landmark on April .His grieving family say they want universities to sound alarm bells when students stop attending classes and offer extra help to all young people suffering from mental health problems, Gloucestershire Live reports.The family described James as an“intelligent, funny and passionate” young man. They have started a fundraising campaign in memory of the popular -year-old from Ross-on-Wye who was a history student at Queen Mary University in London.  A full inquest has yet to determine the official cause of death but a GoFundMe page set up by his elder sister Sapphire in memory of her brother says: “On April , , JJ took his own le at the age of . “He had been struggling with his mental health, the extent of which he had kept hidden from his family and friends.” Describing him has an “intelligent, funny and passionate young man, with strong interests in history and drama”, she said his family and friends have seen it a mission to create change around the stigma of mental health. She says they want to “ensure help is available to young people when they need it most”, and that includes when they are away from home at university and college. “We aim to push for a change in protocols - specically in universities -  to prevent young adults slipping under the radar,” the fundraising page says. “Currently, there is no convention, that we are aware of, where someone is alerted to a signicant change in circumstance - when students stop attending class, for example.  “We learned, following his death, that JJ had not been going to university for at least  months, isolating himself from everyone. “Despite communications with the university, they were unable to inform us of these changes in his attendance. “Had we known,it is possible something could have been done to help him.” Within days, the campaign has raised more than £, towards the charity Rowing Together for Healthy Minds. Donating to the appeal, Joyce Seabrook wrote: JJ was a good friend of mine in first year. We lost contact in the beginning of the year but I have really fond memories of him. His smile and humour were brilliant and he was such a kind person. It’s time that people had more of an awareness of students and their mental health - so we can stop tragic events like this. My thoughts are with you all. Shortly after Jamesapos death senior coroner Alison Hewitt opened an inquest at City of London Coroneraposs Court and said there was a  witness statement which confirmed the young man had fallen to his death. But there were no further details and Ms Hewitt added: “And that has been the evidence which will open this inquest.  “Further evidence has to be gathered, that is taking place as we speak - I am not going to fix a date because the evidence is still being gathered.”  After the inquest his family issued a tribute through City of London Police, saying they were in deep shock at the loss of a beautul, talented and intelligent son who had a deep passion for history  and a wicked sense of humour. “Words cannot adequately express the devastation we feel, nor the love we have for him. The world is inarguably a lesser place without JJ,” they said at the time. Gloucestershire Live has contacted Queen Mary University for comment. Biomedical student Lidia Dragescu, , fell from the same gallery in St Paulaposs in October . The talented figure skater and straight-A pupil was found holding two letters written in her native Romanian. In the letters, she apologised to her mother and said she was “in a better place”. At least  UK University students took their lives in - and according to the Office for National Statistics, suicide is the leading cause of death among young people, leading to calls for more help on campus for those who are struggling. Today an inquest opens into the death of Natasha Abrahart, a second year physics student from Nottingham, who took her own le in April . Her parents Margaret and Robert  face a £, legal bill after deciding they wanted to be legally represented at the  inquest because their daughter was the tenth of  University of Bristol students suspected of taking their own lives since October .If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling

title: historys most famous beards blackbeard
story: NewsHistorys most famous beards - from Blackbeard and Henry VIII to Abraham LincolnHistory is littered with stories of incredible bears - including facial hair that has KILLED and almost started a warShareByJulie McCaffrey:,  MAY NewsPresident Fidel Castro wore his beard as a symbol of triumph "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email More and more men have beards, from the leader of the opposition Jeremy Corbyn to new dad Prince Harry .There have been times when the bare-faced look was preferred, but ­history is not short of its hairy moments. And they do not get hairier than this ­selection of face fuzz-toting folk which History Revealed magazine has put together. Fidel Castro Castro’s beard was part of his public persona and he wore it as a symbol of his triumph during the Cuban Revolution, which was finally victorious on January , . The CIA concocted numerous attempts at assassinations or discrediting him by attacking his image. One plan was to dust his shoes with toxic thallium salts while he travelled overseas, making his beard fall out. However, the trip was cancelled. Despite the CIA’s efforts, Castro’s beard lived to fight another day. Edward Maria Wingfield  As well as keeping your chin warm and for aesthetic appeal, sometimes beards can save your le. Edward Maria Wingfield was one of the financial backers of the Virginia Company of London. They established the colony of Jamestown in Virginia, with Wingfield becoming its first president. During a brutal Native American attack in , Wingfield was shot with an arrow – but only through his beard. The rest of him escaped unscathed. Thomas More  Thomas More was once a trusted mentor to Henry VIII.A deeply religious man, he could not reconcile himself with Henry’s break from the Catholic Church in  in order to orce his first we, Catherineof Aragon.More resigned from his role as Lord Chancellor and refused to swear an oath recognising Henry as the head of the Church of England. Beheaded in , on the chopping block he reportedly laid his beard out of the way and asked the executioner to spare it, noting “this hath not offended the king”. Blackbeard  Blackbeard was feared across the Caribbean Sea and the North American colonies. His nickname apparently came from his thick beard, where he would keep lit fuses to scare enemies. His smouldering whiskers terried some sailors so much they surrendered the moment he stepped on board their ship. His legacy inspired the idea of the pirate as a rogue of the seas. Real name Edward Teach, he was killed in  when cornered by the navy. Hans Steininger  Beards are not normally feared as being dangerous, but for one man excessive facial hair would be the death of him. Hans Steininger was mayor of the town of Braunauin the th century. He was renowned for his beard – believed to measure .ft – which he kept tucked in a pouch. In September , a fire broke out in the town. In the chaos, Steininger tripped over his beard and fell down some stairs, breaking his neck. Annie Jones  PT Barnum’s circus was full of curiosities, including bearded women. One of these was Annie Jones, who joined the show at just nine months old in . Billed as “The Infant Esau” – the biblical Esau being distinguished by his wealth of hair – Jones grew a full beard, moustache and sideburns. This was probably due to hirsutism, a condition that causes excessive body hair. As well as being one of the star attractions, Jones became a spokeswoman for the “freaks” in Barnum’s show and campaigned to rid the circus of the offensive term. Osiris  The Ancient Egyptians strangely preferred  beards to the real thing. Pharaohs, both male and female, would don metallic beards in order to emulate Osiris. The God of the Underworld and Judge of the Dead was often shown with a beard, and burial masks often had them. In , the beard on Tutankhamun’s mask broke and conservators reattached it hastily with glue, scratching the mask. Hans Langseth  The trophy for longest beard goes to Hans Langseth. A native of Norway, he emigrated to the US in . He began growing his beard at  for a local competition and carried on. A farmer by profession, for a while he travelled in a “freak show”. At his death in  it measured .ft. The beard resides in Washington DC’s Smithsonian Institution. Henry VIII  The Tudor king’s beard – or lack of – nearly sent the country into war back in . Henry and Francis I of France were attempting to arrange a meeting. Both kings had promised not to shave until they met one another. But Henry’s we, Catherine of Aragon, was not a fan of her husband’s rugged look and asked him to shave. Francis’ mother took this as a slight against her son and some swt diplomatic flattery was required to restore the peace. Abraham Lincoln  US president Abraham Lincoln is easily recognisable with his full beard. During his early political career, however, he was clean shaven. That was until he received a letter from -year-old Grace Bedell, a month before the  presidential election: “If you will let your whiskers grow, I will try and get the rest of them to vote for you. You would look a great deal better.” Lincoln replied to his young admirer, expressing concern that a beard would look silly. But within the month, he had grown a beard and won the election.

title: we take a look back on 20 years of scottish parliament
story: North-east politicians have hailed some of the Scottish Parliament’s achievements over the last two decades.Among the historic legislation which has been passed by the Government since it was formed  years ago include the smoking ban, minimum unit pricing on alcohol and free prescriptions.North-east Labour MSP Lewis Macdonald said the smoking ban stands out as a notable success, along with changes to land reform to allow communities to buy back assets.He said: “I was the minister tasked with delivering that. It was quite a challenging thing to do.“We knew it would be the right thing to do but we weren’t sure how the public would respond.“We were pleasantly surprised. The other one I would mention would be the land reform legislation.“The community buyout of Bonnymuir Bowling Green was only possible because of that legislation. It’s given the right to communities to take control of their own assets.”Other major policy changes include equal marriage legislation, reducing the drink-drive limit and the controversial decision in  to merge eight regional police forces into Police Scotland – the national police force of Scotland.Kevin Stewart, Aberdeen Central SNP MSP, said: “One of the most profound legacies of the past  was when the Parliament chamber joined together to pass legislation for equal marriage.“Knowing current and future generations of Scots will grow up and build their lives free to love and marry whoever they want to is something we can all be deeply proud of, and should celebrate with pride.”But Mr Stewart added it’s important to “look forward, rather than back”, and consider what actions have been taken to improve the lives of people in Scotland for “decades to come”.He added: “The Scottish Parliament has agreed ambitious climate change targets and could soon move to net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by .“When it comes to our planet we cannot be complacent and that was made clear by the First Minister just over a week ago when she rightly declared a climate emergency.”Sheila Duffy, chief executive of health charity ASH Scotland, said: “It’s hard to believe two decades have passed.“For our work, the establishment of a Scottish Parliament with powers to legislate for health has brought real progress.“Establishing smoke-free public places was an early success and this measure is still delivering positive results.“Since then, progress in Scotland has continued in reducing tobacco use and uptake and putting tobacco products out of sight.”

title: travelling-borderer-returns-from-charitable-adventure

aims to help with water supply issues in some of the worldrsquos poorest countries.Dominic also helped found a charity in Kenya, The Sunflower Community Orphans Support Project.The organization helps feed orphaned children, many of whom are affected by poverty and HIV AIDS, by using the proceeds of a cafeacute selling food to the public.Dominic fully embraced the lestyle of the local community, enduring the same daily struggles faced by the local population.ldquoI experienced what it was like to have electricity and water shortages and to fetch and carry drinking water.ldquoFor the two years I went without washing machines, showers, fridges, cookers, TV or a flushing toilet.His desire to experience the tough reality of le in these societies is perhaps unsurprising given his previous holiday destinations have included North Korea, Chernobyl and the annexed Crimean Peninsula.Despite the dficulties faced by the communities he assisted, Dominic was struck by the gratitude and positivity he encountered. He said: ldquoThe best part was seeing the smiles and laughs of the people I helped.ldquoThey were grateful and happy, and because I lived like the majority of the people in the slum they made feel a part of the community - I really did feel like it was home.This sense of community was demonstrated when a newly born child was named after him, an experience which left Dominic ldquospeechless and overwhelmed.The experiences of his spartan existence during his charitable travels, and the positivity of communities with so few of the things we take for granted, have shaped Dominicrsquos attitude to le since ing to the UK in March.He added: ldquoAfter selling most of my things to help fund this mission I now own very few items and the ones I do own I appreciate more.ldquoI appreciate things like electricity, running water, showers and fridges.ldquoI now live a fairly simple le and, to be honest, I feel happier doing so.

title: shelagh-saddles-up-for-850-miles-humanitarian-charity-cycle
story: A SEMI-RETIRED doctor from the Borders is prescribing some personal pain in a bid to raise much-needed funds for a humanitarian charity that helps survivors of torture.Shelagh King has been delivering babies at Borders General Hospitals maternity ward for decades.And she has also been active member of the Amnesty International inspired Freedom from Torture charity.Later this summer the -year-old from Newstead will team up with a fellow supporter from Edinburgh, Moira Dunworth, to raise vital funds by cycling some  miles around all of the charitys UK centres.Shelagh told us: "We hope to raise awareness about the Freedom from Torture and the people it supports, meet many other supporters, and raise money for the important work."Freedom from Torture provides counselling, medical evidence of torture for legal cases, and general support for people who have suffered torture."Now that I am semi-retired I have the time and when it was mentioned at the AGM that they were looking for people to join in with Moira on part of the fundraising cycle I decided to sign up and give the whole challenge a go."Shelagh and Moira will leave Hastings on Monday, July  and cycle for the next  days zig-zagging across the UK until they reach Edinburgh at the end of the month.Although Shelagh is an enthusiastic member of athletics clubs Gala Harriers and Lauderdale Limpers she admits shes a novice on two wheels.And in preparation for the Cycle Against Torture she is being coached by friend, Tish Mitchell.Shelagh added: "We are working up my distance slowly and have so far managed  miles in one day."I will certainly be well-trained by the time we set off from Hastings."One of the first patients to receive help from Freedom from Torture was Eric Lomax from Berwick Upon Tweed, whose story was told in the film The Railwayman.Eric was tortured as a prisoner of war in Burma.Nowadays people from all over the world who have suffered torture benefit from the charity.Joining Shelagh and Moira for part of their mammoth cycle challenge will be Syrian refugee Violet, who now lives in Glasgow.And they have also won support from world-record cyclist and broadcaster Mark Beaumont.He said: "I am inspired by the efforts of Moira and Shelagh, both retired and taking on an epic cycle ride from Hastings to Edinburgh alongside Violet, a young Syrian refugee."Freedom from Torture is a brilliant grassroots charity providing medical and psychological care for survivors of torture here in the UK and I am sure that this Cycle against Torture will do brilliantly at raising awareness and funds."Chapeau ladies for this adventure of a letime."To support Shelaghs cycle challenge visit https:www.justgiving fundraising shelagh-king

title: council-backs-plans-for-ettrick-4g
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has approved plans to bring G mobile coverage to the Ettrick Valley.Warrington-based WHP Telecoms plans on erecting a  metre-high G tower on Deephope Hill, just off the B between Eskdalemuir and Ettrick.The plans have largely been welcomed by local residents, who cite the current lack of mobile phone signal as a detriment to both the quality of le in the valley and the ability of businesses to thrive.However, they also attracted nine letters of objection, which cited concerns over the height of the mast, the impact on the landscape and the potential detrimental impact on property prices.One supporter, Ogilvie Jackson, of Selkirk, appeared before Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee on Monday to urge councillors to support the plans.He told the committee: ldquoWe have been lobbying very hard to get mobile coverage in the valley.ldquoFor the last three years our neighbours at Ettrick village have enjoyed good coverage due to government funded masts that tower over the settlement.ldquoThe mast before you will give us near perfect G coverage for the Ettrick Valley.ldquoThe proposed site could not be better. In fact compared to some masts in the Borders itrsquos very discreet.ldquoMany motorists have been stranded and unable to secure help because of the lack of phone signal. This mast will make our valley a safer and more self-reliant place to live.ldquoI would say this to the objectors: itrsquos easy to object to a phone mast just because you donrsquot like phone masts. If that happened everywhere there would be no mobile coverage in the country.Councillors sitting on the planning and building standards committee were advised by planning officers that the benefits outweigh the impact of the mastBarry Fotheringham, the councilrsquos principal planning officer, told the committee: ldquoThe proposed mast and associated equipment form part of a national programme to deliver a new mast network and telecommunications coverage in hard to reach areas in Scotland that do not benefit from mobile telephone connectivity.ldquoThe proposed mast will be visible in the landscape but it is considered that the benefits of having a strong telecommunications signal in the Ettrick Valley outweigh the limited and localised landscape and visual impacts.ldquoThe proposed mast will be future-proofed so that it can accommodate other users and G networks. This will avoid the need for a proleration of other masts locally.ldquoThe proposed development complies with the principal policy requirements of the local development plan and is consistent with ensuring that an improved digital infrastructure is available, to ensure people and communities are better connected.While discussing the proposals, councillors were broadly in favour of granting planning permission.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing said: ldquoI have no problem with this application whatsoever. Itrsquos time the Ettrick Valley was brought into the st century.ldquoI absolutely think this is the right decision.Kelso and District councillor Simon Mountford also spoke in favour of the proposals: ldquoIrsquom delighted by this. In this time and age it is unreasonable to expect communities to exist without mobile phone coverage.ldquoAny visual impact is completely outweighed by the economic and social benefits of allowing this application to proceed.Councillors voted unanimously to approve the application.

title: mp-johns-marathon-effort-for-marie-curie
story: BORDERS MP John Lamont completed the London Marathon at the weekend.And the Member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk is also closing in on his fundraising target for Marie Curie Scotland.Mr Lamont was one of the , runners who took to the streets of London on Sunday morning.The -year-old finished the . miles in  hours  minutes and  seconds.John, who was one of  MPs taking part in the race, had set a fundraising target of pound, and he was closing in on the pound, barrier when we went to press.He said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted to have finished the marathon and to have been able to raise some money for a worthwhile cause.ldquoThe crowds lining the streets of the capital were amazing and the atmosphere was electric."It really helps you to keep going to have so many people cheering you on.ldquoIrsquove really appreciated all the messages of support and the donations that have come in for Marie Curie.
